<div data-testid="markdown" class="spacing-loose__3_R8mSIQ2cspwhDGkCOXTu markdown__1eeYJ4WPKUcvX_LDDGJR12 darkTheme__2i0sjr_RjoITRh35Ld2GzM gamut-gk1onf-ArticleMarkdown e1xfx7rd0"><h2 id="heading-introduction" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Introduction</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">A common task you will encounter when programming is iterating over arrays or array-like objects. As a JavaScript programmer, you may already be familiar with the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop. This loop requires a counter, an iteration statement, and a stopping condition to control looping. While powerful, the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop can be a bit cumbersome to set up, introduces room for errors, and could lead to difficult-to-read code.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">As a remedy to some of the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop’s shortcomings, the <a target="_blank" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://www.codecademy.com/articles/javascript-versions">ES6 version</a> of JavaScript introduced the shorter and more concise <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop. This article will outline the benefits of using <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loops and walk through how to use a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop to iterate through arrays and strings. </p>
<h2 id="heading-for-loop-vs-forof-loop" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">for loop vs for…of loop</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Here is an example of iterating over each element in an array using a traditional <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop with an index variable:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const hobbies</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;[</span><span class="mtk8">'singing'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'eating'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'quidditch'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'writing'</span><span class="mtk1">];</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">let i</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">0</span><span class="mtk1">; </span><span class="mtk9">i</span><span class="mtk1"> &lt; </span><span class="mtk9">hobbies</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">length</span><span class="mtk1">; </span><span class="mtk9">i</span><span class="mtk1">++) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk8">`I enjoy </span><span class="mtk1">${</span><span class="mtk9">hobbies</span><span class="mtk1">[</span><span class="mtk9">i</span><span class="mtk1">]}</span><span class="mtk8">.`</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">And here is an example of iterating through the same array using a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const hobbies</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;[</span><span class="mtk8">'singing'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'eating'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'quidditch'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'writing'</span><span class="mtk1">];</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">const hobby</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">of</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">hobbies</span><span class="mtk1">) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk8">`I enjoy </span><span class="mtk1">${</span><span class="mtk9">hobby</span><span class="mtk1">}</span><span class="mtk8">.`</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Both examples print out the same thing: </p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">I enjoy singing.</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">I enjoy eating.</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">I enjoy quidditch.</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">I enjoy writing.</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Notice how the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop has a simpler syntax which can be beneficial for code readability, especially in larger and more complex applications.</p>
<h2 id="heading-iterating-through-an-array" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Iterating Through an Array</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">One of the primary uses of the  <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop is iterating through the items of an array. Let’s breakdown the syntax with a new example:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const fruits</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;[</span><span class="mtk8">'oranges'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'apples'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'grapes'</span><span class="mtk1">];</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">const fruit</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">of</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">fruits</span><span class="mtk1">) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk9">fruit</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Which prints out:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">oranges</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">apples</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">grapes</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Let’s break down the example:</p>
<ol class="ol__1XI8Ausmo9cwwog3NvDzWF">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In our code snippet, we have <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">fruits</code>, which is the array we want to iterate over. </p>
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">We set up our <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop: <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for (const fruit of fruits)</code>. This specifies that we will iterate through the array (<code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">fruits</code>) for each item (<code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">fruit</code>) in the array. </p>
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The variable <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">fruit</code> is assigned a different value on each iteration of the loop. The variable may be declared with the keywords: <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">const</code>, <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">let</code>, or <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">var</code>. You can name the variable anything but it is helpful to use a name related to the iterable object. In the example, notice the placeholder variable uses the singular form of a plural array, <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">fruit</code> of <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">fruits</code>. Here are some other examples: <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">person</code> of a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">people</code> array, <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">puppy</code> of a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">puppies</code> array, etc.</p>
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">For each item in the array, we print the value to the console.</p>
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The loop will start with the first element of the array and stop on the last element. </p>
</li>
</ol>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">There is no need to set up additional variables to store an index with a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop. The loop will iterate over each element in the iterable object and terminate itself when it reaches the last item — so you don’t need to track the number of items in the array. In our example, we used an array, but <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loops also work with strings, sets, and other array-like objects. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Therefore, you should opt for a standard <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop if you need to access the indices or need finer control to determine what elements you want to loop over.</p>
<h2 id="heading-iterating-through-a-string" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Iterating Through a String</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> can also be used to iterate over strings. Here is an example:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const username</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk8">'joe'</span><span class="mtk1">;</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">const char</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">of</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">username</span><span class="mtk1">) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk9">char</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Which prints out:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">j</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">o</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">e</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Notice the similarities between iterating through a string and iterating through an array. The <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop does not change in structure regardless of the iterable object used.</p>
<h2 id="heading-break-and-continue" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Break and Continue</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> has the advantage of setting up most of your loop parameters for you, but sometimes it is necessary to reclaim some control of how iteration is managed. One way of doing this is using JavaScript’s <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">break</code> and <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">continue</code> statements.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">break</code> statement can be used to jump out of a loop. For example:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const strangeBirds</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;[</span><span class="mtk8">'Shoebill'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Cockatrice'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Basan'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Terrorbird'</span><span class="mtk1">,</span><span class="mtk8">'Parotia'</span><span class="mtk1">,</span><span class="mtk8">'Kakapo'</span><span class="mtk1">];</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">const bird</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">of</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">strangeBirds</span><span class="mtk1">) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk12">if</span><span class="mtk1"> (</span><span class="mtk9">bird</span><span class="mtk1"> === </span><span class="mtk8">'Basan'</span><span class="mtk1">){ </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk12">break</span><span class="mtk1">; </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;}</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk9">bird</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Will iterate through the array until it encounters the great mythical <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basan_(legendary_bird)">Basan</a>, then it will exit. This will print out:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">Shoebill</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Cockatrice</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">continue</code> statement is used to skip one iteration of the loop. For example:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const strangeBirds</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;[</span><span class="mtk8">'Shoebill'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Cockatrice'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Basan'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Cow'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Terrorbird'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Parotia'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Kakapo'</span><span class="mtk1">];</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">const bird</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">of</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">strangeBirds</span><span class="mtk1">) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk12">if</span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;(</span><span class="mtk9">bird</span><span class="mtk1"> === </span><span class="mtk8">'Cow'</span><span class="mtk1">){</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk12">continue</span><span class="mtk1">;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;}</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk9">bird</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Will iterate through the array and print out every value except the suspected imposter:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">Shoebill</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Cockatrice</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Basan</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Terrorbird</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Parotia</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Kakapo</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre><h2 id="heading-use-case-for-loop-vs-forof-loop" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Use Case: for loop vs for…of loop</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">You might now be wondering, why use a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop at all if a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop is so much simpler? Well, the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop is not a complete replacement for the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop. Take a look at the following code snippet:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const nums</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;[</span><span class="mtk9">1</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk9">2</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk9">3</span><span class="mtk1">];</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">let i</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">nums</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">length</span><span class="mtk1"> -&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">1</span><span class="mtk1">; </span><span class="mtk9">i</span><span class="mtk1"> &gt;= </span><span class="mtk9">0</span><span class="mtk1">; </span><span class="mtk9">i</span><span class="mtk1">--) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk9">nums</span><span class="mtk1">[</span><span class="mtk9">i</span><span class="mtk1">]);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk8">'Time is up!'</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Which prints:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">3</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">2</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">1</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Time is up! </span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In the example above, we iterated through an array in reverse! You would not be able to use a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop to do the same thing. However, with a regular <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop, you have access to indices of the elements, determine a stopping condition, and the ability to set a counter. Keep these factors in mind when deciding what loop is right for your circumstance. </p>

<ul class="ul__11icM1EC_0uPj3OY0Skp4r">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Understand the benefits of <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code>.</li>

<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx">Use <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">break</code> and <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">continue</code> to control looping in a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop.</li>
</ul>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">There are other <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> type loops in JavaScript that exist for different purposes, such as <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/for...in"><code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...in</code></a>. Be careful to choose the correct type of loop for your situation. The next time you need to iterate through an array, string, or array-like object and don’t need to access the index, consider trying out <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> to keep your code succinct and readable. </p>

## BUILDING INTERACTIVE WEBSITES

### Grammar Checker




<div data-testid="markdown" class="spacing-loose__3_R8mSIQ2cspwhDGkCOXTu markdown__1eeYJ4WPKUcvX_LDDGJR12 darkTheme__2i0sjr_RjoITRh35Ld2GzM gamut-gk1onf-ArticleMarkdown e1xfx7rd0"><h2 id="heading-introduction" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Introduction</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">A common task you will encounter when programming is iterating over arrays or array-like objects. As a JavaScript programmer, you may already be familiar with the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop. This loop requires a counter, an iteration statement, and a stopping condition to control looping. While powerful, the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop can be a bit cumbersome to set up, introduces room for errors, and could lead to difficult-to-read code.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">As a remedy to some of the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop’s shortcomings, the <a target="_blank" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://www.codecademy.com/articles/javascript-versions">ES6 version</a> of JavaScript introduced the shorter and more concise <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop. This article will outline the benefits of using <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loops and walk through how to use a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop to iterate through arrays and strings. </p>
<h2 id="heading-for-loop-vs-forof-loop" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">for loop vs for…of loop</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Here is an example of iterating over each element in an array using a traditional <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop with an index variable:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const hobbies</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;[</span><span class="mtk8">'singing'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'eating'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'quidditch'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'writing'</span><span class="mtk1">];</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">let i</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">0</span><span class="mtk1">; </span><span class="mtk9">i</span><span class="mtk1"> &lt; </span><span class="mtk9">hobbies</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">length</span><span class="mtk1">; </span><span class="mtk9">i</span><span class="mtk1">++) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk8">`I enjoy </span><span class="mtk1">${</span><span class="mtk9">hobbies</span><span class="mtk1">[</span><span class="mtk9">i</span><span class="mtk1">]}</span><span class="mtk8">.`</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">And here is an example of iterating through the same array using a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const hobbies</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;[</span><span class="mtk8">'singing'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'eating'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'quidditch'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'writing'</span><span class="mtk1">];</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">const hobby</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">of</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">hobbies</span><span class="mtk1">) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk8">`I enjoy </span><span class="mtk1">${</span><span class="mtk9">hobby</span><span class="mtk1">}</span><span class="mtk8">.`</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Both examples print out the same thing: </p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">I enjoy singing.</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">I enjoy eating.</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">I enjoy quidditch.</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">I enjoy writing.</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Notice how the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop has a simpler syntax which can be beneficial for code readability, especially in larger and more complex applications.</p>
<h2 id="heading-iterating-through-an-array" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Iterating Through an Array</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">One of the primary uses of the  <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop is iterating through the items of an array. Let’s breakdown the syntax with a new example:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const fruits</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;[</span><span class="mtk8">'oranges'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'apples'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'grapes'</span><span class="mtk1">];</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">const fruit</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">of</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">fruits</span><span class="mtk1">) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk9">fruit</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Which prints out:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">oranges</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">apples</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">grapes</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Let’s break down the example:</p>
<ol class="ol__1XI8Ausmo9cwwog3NvDzWF">
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In our code snippet, we have <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">fruits</code>, which is the array we want to iterate over. </p>
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">We set up our <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop: <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for (const fruit of fruits)</code>. This specifies that we will iterate through the array (<code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">fruits</code>) for each item (<code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">fruit</code>) in the array. </p>
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The variable <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">fruit</code> is assigned a different value on each iteration of the loop. The variable may be declared with the keywords: <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">const</code>, <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">let</code>, or <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">var</code>. You can name the variable anything but it is helpful to use a name related to the iterable object. In the example, notice the placeholder variable uses the singular form of a plural array, <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">fruit</code> of <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">fruits</code>. Here are some other examples: <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">person</code> of a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">people</code> array, <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">puppy</code> of a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">puppies</code> array, etc.</p>
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">For each item in the array, we print the value to the console.</p>
</li>
<li class="li__1KqBjwbWA3ze6V0BvXq9Rx"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The loop will start with the first element of the array and stop on the last element. </p>
</li>
</ol>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">There is no need to set up additional variables to store an index with a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop. The loop will iterate over each element in the iterable object and terminate itself when it reaches the last item — so you don’t need to track the number of items in the array. In our example, we used an array, but <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loops also work with strings, sets, and other array-like objects. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Therefore, you should opt for a standard <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop if you need to access the indices or need finer control to determine what elements you want to loop over.</p>
<h2 id="heading-iterating-through-a-string" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Iterating Through a String</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> can also be used to iterate over strings. Here is an example:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const username</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk8">'joe'</span><span class="mtk1">;</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">const char</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">of</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">username</span><span class="mtk1">) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk9">char</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Which prints out:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">j</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">o</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">e</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Notice the similarities between iterating through a string and iterating through an array. The <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop does not change in structure regardless of the iterable object used.</p>
<h2 id="heading-break-and-continue" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Break and Continue</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> has the advantage of setting up most of your loop parameters for you, but sometimes it is necessary to reclaim some control of how iteration is managed. One way of doing this is using JavaScript’s <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">break</code> and <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">continue</code> statements.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">break</code> statement can be used to jump out of a loop. For example:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const strangeBirds</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;[</span><span class="mtk8">'Shoebill'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Cockatrice'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Basan'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Terrorbird'</span><span class="mtk1">,</span><span class="mtk8">'Parotia'</span><span class="mtk1">,</span><span class="mtk8">'Kakapo'</span><span class="mtk1">];</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">const bird</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">of</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">strangeBirds</span><span class="mtk1">) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk12">if</span><span class="mtk1"> (</span><span class="mtk9">bird</span><span class="mtk1"> === </span><span class="mtk8">'Basan'</span><span class="mtk1">){ </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk12">break</span><span class="mtk1">; </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;}</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk9">bird</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Will iterate through the array until it encounters the great mythical <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basan_(legendary_bird)">Basan</a>, then it will exit. This will print out:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">Shoebill</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Cockatrice</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">continue</code> statement is used to skip one iteration of the loop. For example:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const strangeBirds</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;[</span><span class="mtk8">'Shoebill'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Cockatrice'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Basan'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Cow'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Terrorbird'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Parotia'</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk8">'Kakapo'</span><span class="mtk1">];</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">const bird</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">of</span><span class="mtk1"> </span><span class="mtk12">strangeBirds</span><span class="mtk1">) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk12">if</span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;(</span><span class="mtk9">bird</span><span class="mtk1"> === </span><span class="mtk8">'Cow'</span><span class="mtk1">){</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk12">continue</span><span class="mtk1">;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;}</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk9">bird</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Will iterate through the array and print out every value except the suspected imposter:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">Shoebill</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Cockatrice</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Basan</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Terrorbird</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Parotia</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Kakapo</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre><h2 id="heading-use-case-for-loop-vs-forof-loop" class="h2__1Ly_Sza5xVS3yZl46_StcN">Use Case: for loop vs for…of loop</h2>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">You might now be wondering, why use a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop at all if a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop is so much simpler? Well, the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop is not a complete replacement for the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop. Take a look at the following code snippet:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">const nums</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;[</span><span class="mtk9">1</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk9">2</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk9">3</span><span class="mtk1">];</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">let i</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">nums</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">length</span><span class="mtk1"> -&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">1</span><span class="mtk1">; </span><span class="mtk9">i</span><span class="mtk1"> &gt;= </span><span class="mtk9">0</span><span class="mtk1">; </span><span class="mtk9">i</span><span class="mtk1">--) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk9">nums</span><span class="mtk1">[</span><span class="mtk9">i</span><span class="mtk1">]);</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br><span><span> </span></span><br><span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk8">'Time is up!'</span><span class="mtk1">);</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Which prints:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="plaintext" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk1">3</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">2</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">1</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">Time is up! </span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In the example above, we iterated through an array in reverse! You would not be able to use a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for...of</code> loop to do the same thing. However, with a regular <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">for</code> loop, you have access to indices of the elements, determine a stopping condition, and the ability to set a counter. Keep these factors in mind when deciding what loop is right for your circumstance. </p>

## Thinking About Errors in Your Code Differently




<div data-testid="markdown" class="spacing-loose__3_R8mSIQ2cspwhDGkCOXTu markdown__1eeYJ4WPKUcvX_LDDGJR12 darkTheme__2i0sjr_RjoITRh35Ld2GzM gamut-gk1onf-ArticleMarkdown e1xfx7rd0"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">When you get started with coding, it’s inevitable that bugs will show up in your code. You’ll get unintended behaviors and you even get a long, possibly scary looking, error alongside your bug(s). Even when you’re a seasoned coder you’ll continue to encounter bugs and errors — that’s a good thing! It’s important to understand that making and debugging errors is part of the process and you won’t always know the solution right away. In this article, you learn how to find the bug that’s causing your error, and how to think about the debugging process differently.</p>
<h3 id="heading-red-is-a-beautiful-color" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Red is a Beautiful Color</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Red can be a dangerous color. STOP, DANGER, DO NOT ENTER, all loud red signs telling us to turn around, don’t go in there, you’ll get hurt. It’s easy to carry this mindset over to coding that many new programmers get discouraged and distraught over the red error messages that appear in the terminal.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">They think, “oh no, I’ve done something wrong again” and “clearly coding isn’t for me, even the computer knows,” but that’s the wrong way of thinking! All programmers, even the most experienced ones, get errors all the time. Believe it or not, experienced programmers likely face far more errors than a new programmer ever will.</p>
<h3 id="heading-errors-in-your-code-mean-youre-trying-to-do-something-cool" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Errors in Your Code Mean You’re Trying To Do Something Cool</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Consider the totally made up graph below:</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://news.codecademy.com/content/images/2018/07/image3-1.png" alt="A chart depicting a linear correlation between the number of errors you'll encounter in your code and the complexity of your code." class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">As your code increases in complexity, the number of errors you’ll encounter rises at a similar rate. An error means you’re trying to do something that might be a little complicated (or very complicated), and it doesn’t quite work yet, but by no means is it a sign that you should stop trying!</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In fact, there are entire engineering roles built around finding and fixing errors. A <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Site_Reliability_Engineering">site reliability engineer</a> finds and report errors in web platforms. A <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_engineer">test engineer</a> builds automated tests to discover errors in software and make sure that it meets a companies standards.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Almost all major technology companies offer cash rewards to intrepid programmers who can find bugs in their software. <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://www.google.com/about/appsecurity/reward-program/">Google</a>, <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://aws.amazon.com/security/vulnerability-reporting/">Amazon</a>, and <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn425036.aspx">Microsoft</a> all encourage users to seek out bugs and report any they might find.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Why do they do this? Why would a major technology company want its users to try to break their software? Because they understand that encountering bugs is one of the best ways you can improve your code. Bugs show you where the weaknesses are, make you really consider what you want your code to accomplish, and then guide you towards building more reliable and secure products.</p>
<h3 id="heading-tools-to-tackle-code-errors" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Tools to Tackle Code Errors</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Okay, okay, that makes sense! Error messages shouldn’t be scary, but tackling them and coming up with a solution is still a skill that must be developed. Being willing to tackle an error is a great first step, and having some tools at your disposal to debug is a great way to feel comfortable tackling even the gnarliest of bugs in the future.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Let’s outline a few steps you can take to solve any compiler errors that you might encounter – these types of errors print out to the console.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The following steps will guide you through a standard error that might get thrown your way as you learn to code, and they’ll show you that errors aren’t as scary as they seem. In fact, the steps are mostly a combination of reading the error carefully and copying and pasting it in a web search!</p>
<h3 id="heading-1-dissect-the-error" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">1. Dissect the Error.</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">When an error first appears on your screen, find the line in the error specific to your code. Lots of error messages have tons of boilerplate details that aren’t important to the actual error. You want to find the part of the error message that gives you insight about what happened. That line is generally at the top of the error stack trace.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Let’s take a look at a plausible error that you could encounter when writing a program that finds students on the honor roll among a list of students based on their GPA. Given the list, you might want to filter for all of the honor roll students by looking at the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">gpa</code> property.</p>

<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The first line says that the JavaScript engine doesn’t think that <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.filter()</code> is a function — but it should be, so there might be an issue in how it’s being used. The second line points to the line of code that is throwing the error, which is line 21 and at the 26th character: <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">let honorRoll = students.filter(student =&gt; {...</code>.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The code is calling <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.filter()</code> on the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">students</code> variable. Checking back in on the code, you can see that <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">students</code> is an object. This seems like a good place to start.</p>
<h3 id="heading-2-ask-yourself-is-the-solution-in-the-error" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">2. Ask Yourself, Is the Solution In the Error?</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Often, you’ll encounter syntax errors that will show exactly where the error occurred and what the error was. When you get these types of errors, you can go directly back to your code and fix them. Here’s an example of code that will throw a syntax error:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><pre><code><div data-lang="codecademy-js" class="gamut-1csnpkx-ColorizedContainer e1hgti5c0"><span><span class="mtk12">for </span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk12">let x</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">0</span><span class="mtk1">; </span><span class="mtk9">x</span><span class="mtk1"> &lt; </span><span class="mtk9">10</span><span class="mtk1">, </span><span class="mtk9">x</span><span class="mtk1">++) {</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk9">console</span><span class="mtk1">.</span><span class="mtk10">log</span><span class="mtk1">(</span><span class="mtk9">x</span><span class="mtk1">)</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk1">}</span></span><br></div></code></pre></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Running this code will output:</p>
<pre class="pre__3_SOs7YT7NaHjnNunEArSM"><code class="errorBlock__2oVHQQnsjhJzzFnkMpHhy3 code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS language-error">/home/runner/FearlessNewDev/index.js:1
for (let x = 0; x &lt; 10, x++) {
                           ^

SyntaxError: Unexpected token ')'</code></pre>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Notice that in this case, the compiler is pointing to the syntax issue with the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">^</code> symbol, which sometimes makes it easier to debug. However, the issue is that there’s accidentally a comma (<code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">,</code>) instead of a semicolon (<code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">;</code>). Error messages can help, but you still need to use your developer knowledge to fix the error!</p>
<h3 id="heading-3-search-on-the-web-for-instances-of-this-error" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">3. Search on the Web for Instances of This Error.</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Sometimes, step 2 will not apply, and you’ll have to dive a little deeper into the error. Let’s return to the honor roll error that came up in step one. Since the solution isn’t immediately obvious, you’ll need to do some research to understand why it flagged an error.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Copy and paste the important part of the error message into a search engine and look through the results until you find someone else who has also run into that issue. To get better search results, you can include relevant keywords and modify the error message to be more generic.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In the error message <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">TypeError: students.filter is not a function</code>, it’s highly unlikely that someone else is having a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.filter()</code> issue on a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">students</code> variable with the same data types, so that’s the type of thing that could be more generic. Instead of searching for “TypeError: students.filter is not a function”, you can try something like “TypeError: object filter() is not a function” and add a keyword for the language. The final search might be: “TypeError: object filter() is not a function JavaScript”.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">After searching, one of the first results looks promising: “filter is a method on arrays. Since the code you posted contains an object, you’re seeing this error. You may want to apply filter after…” </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Aha! If you consult the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.filter()</code> documentation on <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/filter">MDN Web Docs</a> you can confirm that <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.filter()</code> is only for arrays. On the Stack Overflow page, it recommends using <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Object.keys(data)</code> to turn the object into an iterable array so you can use the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.filter()</code> <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Array</code> method on the new array.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Google is always a good place to check, but you can also reread documentation on MDN Web Docs or search directly on Stack Overflow, which is a wonderful community of programmers sharing knowledge and building cool stuff.</p>
<h3 id="heading-4-compare-different-use-cases-to-yours" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">4. Compare Different Use Cases to Yours.</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Often you will not find someone who was trying to do the exact same thing you were trying to do, but who still encountered the same error. Read through their code a bit and see if it is comparable to yours. Even if their code is wildly different, the one or two lines that threw the error might be very similar to your code, so the solution may end up being the same.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Consider the result found for the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">TypeError</code>. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://static-assets.codecademy.com/Courses/errors-and-error-handling/typeerror_stackoverflow.png" alt="The screenshot shows a suggested solution on the forum Stack Overflow and includes a code snippet with a possible solution for the error message." class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Even though the solution didn’t involve a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">students</code> object, the answer does provide a quick way to make an <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Object</code> work with the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.filter()</code> method. It’s worth a shot to try it!</p>
<h3 id="heading-5-try-to-implement-the-solution" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">5. Try to implement the solution.</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Tweak the code a bit to match your use case and try it out! Worst case is that the error doesn’t go away and then you can try again. Best case is that it’s fixed and you’ve learned what was causing your error!</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Every solution you implement is a new tool you can add to your programmer’s toolbox, and another error you will know how to solve in the future.</p>

<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In the process of figuring out this compiler error, you were able to learn how to use <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Array</code> methods on objects, and how to think about your use of data types. See, every error is an opportunity to learn!</p>
<h3 id="heading-6-if-it-doesnt-work-repeat-steps-2-4" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">6. If It Doesn’t Work, Repeat Steps 2-4.</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Keep searching through Google and Stack Overflow. The answer will be there! Sometimes it’s helpful to Google parts of the error message, use <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">console.log()</code> to see the outputs, or to read about methods and data types at the website <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript">MDN Web Docs</a>.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The solutions to your errors are out there, and the process of finding them will make you a stronger and more confident programmer. As you grow and learn, expect to encounter countless errors, and expect each one to be its own unique learning opportunity.</p>
<h3 id="heading-7-ask-the-question-yourself" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">7. Ask The Question Yourself.</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Okay, maybe the answer isn’t out there… yet. There is a wealth of information out on the web, but you might be the first one doing something completely new and shiny. It’s ok to ask for help. On the same sites and forums that you found help from, post a question. Ideally, you supply all the background information and provide relevant code that others can look at and do their best to help you out.</p>
<h3 id="heading-wrap-up" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Wrap up</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Remember that bugs are a good thing: finding bugs gives you the opportunity to make your code stronger and more secure. Debugging is a learning opportunity, and other programmers have encountered similar issues and had to ask a lot of the same questions before you. So don’t reinvent the wheel; instead, tap into the pool of solved bugs and learning opportunities available on sites like Stack Overflow, or other resources that can turn up in a web search. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">When debugging, remember that you can generalize your error messages or use keywords to make searches more relevant. Don’t be afraid of reading through the documentation either; MDN offers a great option for that. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Most importantly, as you continue growing your debugging tool belt, remember that everyone who has learned before you has encountered a lot of the same bugs, and has asked the same questions online, so don’t be afraid to try a lot of new ideas and ask questions during the debugging process!</p>

## DEBUGGING JAVASCRIPT CODE

### Debugging Overview




<div data-testid="markdown" class="spacing-loose__3_R8mSIQ2cspwhDGkCOXTu markdown__1eeYJ4WPKUcvX_LDDGJR12 darkTheme__2i0sjr_RjoITRh35Ld2GzM gamut-gk1onf-ArticleMarkdown e1xfx7rd0"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">When you get started with coding, it’s inevitable that bugs will show up in your code. You’ll get unintended behaviors and you even get a long, possibly scary looking, error alongside your bug(s). Even when you’re a seasoned coder you’ll continue to encounter bugs and errors — that’s a good thing! It’s important to understand that making and debugging errors is part of the process and you won’t always know the solution right away. In this article, you learn how to find the bug that’s causing your error, and how to think about the debugging process differently.</p>
<h3 id="heading-red-is-a-beautiful-color" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Red is a Beautiful Color</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Red can be a dangerous color. STOP, DANGER, DO NOT ENTER, all loud red signs telling us to turn around, don’t go in there, you’ll get hurt. It’s easy to carry this mindset over to coding that many new programmers get discouraged and distraught over the red error messages that appear in the terminal.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">They think, “oh no, I’ve done something wrong again” and “clearly coding isn’t for me, even the computer knows,” but that’s the wrong way of thinking! All programmers, even the most experienced ones, get errors all the time. Believe it or not, experienced programmers likely face far more errors than a new programmer ever will.</p>
<h3 id="heading-errors-in-your-code-mean-youre-trying-to-do-something-cool" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Errors in Your Code Mean You’re Trying To Do Something Cool</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Consider the totally made up graph below:</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://news.codecademy.com/content/images/2018/07/image3-1.png" alt="A chart depicting a linear correlation between the number of errors you'll encounter in your code and the complexity of your code." class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">As your code increases in complexity, the number of errors you’ll encounter rises at a similar rate. An error means you’re trying to do something that might be a little complicated (or very complicated), and it doesn’t quite work yet, but by no means is it a sign that you should stop trying!</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In fact, there are entire engineering roles built around finding and fixing errors. A <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Site_Reliability_Engineering">site reliability engineer</a> finds and report errors in web platforms. A <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_engineer">test engineer</a> builds automated tests to discover errors in software and make sure that it meets a companies standards.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Almost all major technology companies offer cash rewards to intrepid programmers who can find bugs in their software. <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://www.google.com/about/appsecurity/reward-program/">Google</a>, <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://aws.amazon.com/security/vulnerability-reporting/">Amazon</a>, and <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn425036.aspx">Microsoft</a> all encourage users to seek out bugs and report any they might find.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Why do they do this? Why would a major technology company want its users to try to break their software? Because they understand that encountering bugs is one of the best ways you can improve your code. Bugs show you where the weaknesses are, make you really consider what you want your code to accomplish, and then guide you towards building more reliable and secure products.</p>
<h3 id="heading-tools-to-tackle-code-errors" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Tools to Tackle Code Errors</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Okay, okay, that makes sense! Error messages shouldn’t be scary, but tackling them and coming up with a solution is still a skill that must be developed. Being willing to tackle an error is a great first step, and having some tools at your disposal to debug is a great way to feel comfortable tackling even the gnarliest of bugs in the future.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Let’s outline a few steps you can take to solve any compiler errors that you might encounter – these types of errors print out to the console.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The following steps will guide you through a standard error that might get thrown your way as you learn to code, and they’ll show you that errors aren’t as scary as they seem. In fact, the steps are mostly a combination of reading the error carefully and copying and pasting it in a web search!</p>
<h3 id="heading-1-dissect-the-error" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">1. Dissect the Error.</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">When an error first appears on your screen, find the line in the error specific to your code. Lots of error messages have tons of boilerplate details that aren’t important to the actual error. You want to find the part of the error message that gives you insight about what happened. That line is generally at the top of the error stack trace.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Let’s take a look at a plausible error that you could encounter when writing a program that finds students on the honor roll among a list of students based on their GPA. Given the list, you might want to filter for all of the honor roll students by looking at the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">gpa</code> property.</p>

<h3 id="heading-2-ask-yourself-is-the-solution-in-the-error" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">2. Ask Yourself, Is the Solution In the Error?</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Often, you’ll encounter syntax errors that will show exactly where the error occurred and what the error was. When you get these types of errors, you can go directly back to your code and fix them. Here’s an example of code that will throw a syntax error:</p>

Error messages can help, but you still need to use your developer knowledge to fix the error!</p>
<h3 id="heading-3-search-on-the-web-for-instances-of-this-error" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">3. Search on the Web for Instances of This Error.</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Sometimes, step 2 will not apply, and you’ll have to dive a little deeper into the error. Let’s return to the honor roll error that came up in step one. Since the solution isn’t immediately obvious, you’ll need to do some research to understand why it flagged an error.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Copy and paste the important part of the error message into a search engine and look through the results until you find someone else who has also run into that issue. To get better search results, you can include relevant keywords and modify the error message to be more generic.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In the error message <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">TypeError: students.filter is not a function</code>, it’s highly unlikely that someone else is having a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.filter()</code> issue on a <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">students</code> variable with the same data types, so that’s the type of thing that could be more generic. Instead of searching for “TypeError: students.filter is not a function”, you can try something like “TypeError: object filter() is not a function” and add a keyword for the language. The final search might be: “TypeError: object filter() is not a function JavaScript”.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">After searching, one of the first results looks promising: “filter is a method on arrays. Since the code you posted contains an object, you’re seeing this error. You may want to apply filter after…” </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Aha! If you consult the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.filter()</code> documentation on <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/filter">MDN Web Docs</a> you can confirm that <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.filter()</code> is only for arrays. On the Stack Overflow page, it recommends using <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Object.keys(data)</code> to turn the object into an iterable array so you can use the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">.filter()</code> <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">Array</code> method on the new array.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Google is always a good place to check, but you can also reread documentation on MDN Web Docs or search directly on Stack Overflow, which is a wonderful community of programmers sharing knowledge and building cool stuff.</p>
<h3 id="heading-4-compare-different-use-cases-to-yours" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">4. Compare Different Use Cases to Yours.</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Often you will not find someone who was trying to do the exact same thing you were trying to do, but who still encountered the same error. Read through their code a bit and see if it is comparable to yours. Even if their code is wildly different, the one or two lines that threw the error might be very similar to your code, so the solution may end up being the same.</p>

<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Every solution you implement is a new tool you can add to your programmer’s toolbox, and another error you will know how to solve in the future.</p>

<h3 id="heading-6-if-it-doesnt-work-repeat-steps-2-4" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">6. If It Doesn’t Work, Repeat Steps 2-4.</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Keep searching through Google and Stack Overflow. The answer will be there! Sometimes it’s helpful to Google parts of the error message, use <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">console.log()</code> to see the outputs, or to read about methods and data types at the website <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript">MDN Web Docs</a>.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The solutions to your errors are out there, and the process of finding them will make you a stronger and more confident programmer. As you grow and learn, expect to encounter countless errors, and expect each one to be its own unique learning opportunity.</p>
<h3 id="heading-7-ask-the-question-yourself" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">7. Ask The Question Yourself.</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Okay, maybe the answer isn’t out there… yet. There is a wealth of information out on the web, but you might be the first one doing something completely new and shiny. It’s ok to ask for help. On the same sites and forums that you found help from, post a question. Ideally, you supply all the background information and provide relevant code that others can look at and do their best to help you out.</p>
<h3 id="heading-wrap-up" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Wrap up</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Remember that bugs are a good thing: finding bugs gives you the opportunity to make your code stronger and more secure. Debugging is a learning opportunity, and other programmers have encountered similar issues and had to ask a lot of the same questions before you. So don’t reinvent the wheel; instead, tap into the pool of solved bugs and learning opportunities available on sites like Stack Overflow, or other resources that can turn up in a web search. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">When debugging, remember that you can generalize your error messages or use keywords to make searches more relevant. Don’t be afraid of reading through the documentation either; MDN offers a great option for that. </p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Most importantly, as you continue growing your debugging tool belt, remember that everyone who has learned before you has encountered a lot of the same bugs, and has asked the same questions online, so don’t be afraid to try a lot of new ideas and ask questions during the debugging process!</p>

## DEBUGGING JAVASCRIPT CODE

### Error Stack Traces




<div data-testid="markdown" class="spacing-loose__3_R8mSIQ2cspwhDGkCOXTu markdown__1eeYJ4WPKUcvX_LDDGJR12 darkTheme__2i0sjr_RjoITRh35Ld2GzM gamut-gk1onf-ArticleMarkdown e1xfx7rd0"><p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">When you get started with coding, it’s inevitable that bugs will show up in your code. You’ll get unintended behaviors and you even get a long, possibly scary looking, error alongside your bug(s). Even when you’re a seasoned coder you’ll continue to encounter bugs and errors — that’s a good thing! It’s important to understand that making and debugging errors is part of the process and you won’t always know the solution right away. In this article, you learn how to find the bug that’s causing your error, and how to think about the debugging process differently.</p>
<h3 id="heading-red-is-a-beautiful-color" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Red is a Beautiful Color</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Red can be a dangerous color. STOP, DANGER, DO NOT ENTER, all loud red signs telling us to turn around, don’t go in there, you’ll get hurt. It’s easy to carry this mindset over to coding that many new programmers get discouraged and distraught over the red error messages that appear in the terminal.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">They think, “oh no, I’ve done something wrong again” and “clearly coding isn’t for me, even the computer knows,” but that’s the wrong way of thinking! All programmers, even the most experienced ones, get errors all the time. Believe it or not, experienced programmers likely face far more errors than a new programmer ever will.</p>
<h3 id="heading-errors-in-your-code-mean-youre-trying-to-do-something-cool" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Errors in Your Code Mean You’re Trying To Do Something Cool</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Consider the totally made up graph below:</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw"><img src="https://news.codecademy.com/content/images/2018/07/image3-1.png" alt="A chart depicting a linear correlation between the number of errors you'll encounter in your code and the complexity of your code." class="img__1JGFO2nlisObc3KeOSGPRp"></p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">As your code increases in complexity, the number of errors you’ll encounter rises at a similar rate. An error means you’re trying to do something that might be a little complicated (or very complicated), and it doesn’t quite work yet, but by no means is it a sign that you should stop trying!</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">In fact, there are entire engineering roles built around finding and fixing errors. A <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Site_Reliability_Engineering">site reliability engineer</a> finds and report errors in web platforms. A <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_engineer">test engineer</a> builds automated tests to discover errors in software and make sure that it meets a companies standards.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Almost all major technology companies offer cash rewards to intrepid programmers who can find bugs in their software. <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://www.google.com/about/appsecurity/reward-program/">Google</a>, <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://aws.amazon.com/security/vulnerability-reporting/">Amazon</a>, and <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="e14vpv2g1 gamut-xro1w8-ResetElement-Anchor-AnchorBase e1bhhzie0" href="https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn425036.aspx">Microsoft</a> all encourage users to seek out bugs and report any they might find.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Why do they do this? Why would a major technology company want its users to try to break their software? Because they understand that encountering bugs is one of the best ways you can improve your code. Bugs show you where the weaknesses are, make you really consider what you want your code to accomplish, and then guide you towards building more reliable and secure products.</p>
<h3 id="heading-tools-to-tackle-code-errors" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">Tools to Tackle Code Errors</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Okay, okay, that makes sense! Error messages shouldn’t be scary, but tackling them and coming up with a solution is still a skill that must be developed. Being willing to tackle an error is a great first step, and having some tools at your disposal to debug is a great way to feel comfortable tackling even the gnarliest of bugs in the future.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Let’s outline a few steps you can take to solve any compiler errors that you might encounter – these types of errors print out to the console.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">The following steps will guide you through a standard error that might get thrown your way as you learn to code, and they’ll show you that errors aren’t as scary as they seem. In fact, the steps are mostly a combination of reading the error carefully and copying and pasting it in a web search!</p>
<h3 id="heading-1-dissect-the-error" class="h3__3B1DSzXTW-ux1viDSStOux">1. Dissect the Error.</h3>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">When an error first appears on your screen, find the line in the error specific to your code. Lots of error messages have tons of boilerplate details that aren’t important to the actual error. You want to find the part of the error message that gives you insight about what happened. That line is generally at the top of the error stack trace.</p>
<p class="p__1qg33Igem5pAgn4kPMirjw">Let’s take a look at a plausible error that you could encounter when writing a program that finds students on the honor roll among a list of students based on their GPA. Given the list, you might want to filter for all of the honor roll students by looking at the <code class="code__2rdF32qjRVp7mMVBHuPwDS">gpa</code> property.</p>

class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;</span><span class="mtk4">3.5</span><span class="mtk1">;</span></span><br><span><span class="mtk12">let students</span><span class="mtk1"> =&nbsp;{</span></span><br><span><span
